review_content: It was exceptionally difficult opening the remote to install the batteries. Believe that I have a ‚Äúfix‚Äù for the issue. I assume no liability if someone injures themselves using a knife or screwdriver.1.  Put on a pair of latex gloves.2.  Following the instructions, press hard on the cover (which happens to be constructed with a very stiff plastic) and push it towards the rear of the remote. Little by little the cover will start to move a mm or so at a time. This is a difficult step. Do not under any circumstances  be tempted to use a knife or any other tool which might cause injury to yourself or damage the remote.3. Continue (2) until the cover slides completely off.4. Do not install batteries yet. IMPORTANT.5. Place the cover back onto the remote and and carefully slide it to approximately 2mm of being closed. No force should be required at this point. If cover locks up again go back to step (2) and repeat.6. Repeat sliding the cover back and forth 20 or so times. This will remove any tiny burrs on the cover of the remote.7.  Open completely and install batteries following the instructions.8. Cover should now slide open with minimal effort.

review_content: For starters, Amazon tends to lump reviews for similar items together. This review is for "All-new Fire TV Stick with Alexa Voice Remote (includes *SOME* TV controls) | HD streaming device | 2020 release" This is the 1080p model . I do not own, nor need support for 4K. My eyesight isn't fantastic, and I can enjoy 1080p on a 46" screen just fine.I have a previous generation Fire Stick that I use for one of the bedroom TVs.My wife quickly overran the meager 8GB internal memory on the original Fire Stick, and at the time I checked it out, the original did NOT support USB flash drives as any sort of storage. Reading the Q&A here with these and yes, it seemed flash drives via a USB OTG cable were supported now on this model, not the older one. I plugged in the new fire stick, powered it up, and did the initial configuration and grabbed the latest updates. THEN I turned it off, unplugged the power, plugged in a USB OTG cable, make sure it has male, and female micro USB and a regular USB female port, plug in the flash drive, then my Fire stick ethernet adapter as I prefer wired eithernet over WiFi for reliability sake / less lag.... and lastly plug the power feed back in and turn it all on... I get prompted to format, so I formatted to device storage.Mind you, this Fire Stick shows 6GB instead of the old 8GB, NOT an improvement, but it supports a 128GB flash drive as device storage but shows 121GB, I figure the new version of FireOS is counting storage funny. Either way I have at least 126 GB of total storage for apps and data. Not going to hold my movies on it, but it sure won't run out of space for apps.The older fire stick wasn't super stable either. Closing apps and opening new ones like switching from Hulu to Prime Video would often crash it requiing a reboot. No instability noticed at all with this one.Operational response such as mentioned above is not only more stable, but noticably faster. I don't know if the specs changed that much, but it sure does seem to run quicker with far less wait / load time for apps.The remote is new as well. Not sure what they did other than more integrated TV control, but the mic for the Alexa remote works much better than previous versions.  But where it really has improved, but has a ways to go still is TV control. I can change volume, and of course bring up the Fire stick, but being able to change inputs, and change channels on live OTA TV is still in dream territory for me here. It is nice however when streaming movies and web shows to not have to dig up the TV remote to change the volume.... And of course the ability to handle this via Alexa is nice too...For my TV I switch between the fire stick a PS4, a Wii (Yeah I still use one of those), and an Atari Flashback, I still need a TV remote. Hopefully some day Amazon will upgrade the remote for this to integrate those controls somehow....
title: Almost perfect.

author: David N.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2020
review_content: I ordered the new 2020 version Fire TV Stick for our upstairs TV and quickly received a brand new sealed product.  I opened the package, plugged it into a spare HDMI port, and connected it to power.  The screen indicated it was waiting to pair with the remote so I installed the included batteries.  The remote quickly paired and the next screen was to select my language.  I selected the English default and it then indicated it was checking for software updates.  What the heck?  It never asked me for WiFi credentials so how could it look for updates?  And then it was downloading the update, from I didn't know where.  It installed the update, restarted, and downloaded another update.  At this point I was really confused.  The second software update installed and then it restarted one more time.  And this time, it had my name on the screen, asking me if I wanted to use my Prime account or enter a different one.  How did it know?  I had entered exactly zero user information, zero WiFi network information, and it simply connected to my network and connected to my Prime account.  This was so easy!  But, how could it do this?  It then asked me to try the remote volume control confirm it worked with the TV sound.  It worked.  It never even asked me what model TV it was connected to.  When I clicked the remote power button, the TV turned off.  Again, how did it know how to control the TV?The only thing I can figure is the new Fire TV Stick scanned for other Fire TV Sticks over an alternate WiFi channel, connected to an older Fire TV Stick we have, and retrieved the account and connection information.  If so, this is brilliant!As for the TV pairing, I suspect that while it was transmitting different audio tones during setup, it was transmitting different TV remote audio control commands while the remote microphone was listening for volume changes.  When it sensed a change, it had found the correct TV remote encoding.  Again, brilliant!Setup can not get any easier than this.  It works great!EDIT:  Upon further research, I found that Amazon can save your account and WiFi credentials in the cloud to automatically connect new devices, so perhaps this information was configured into the device when ordered.
